headline: Ron Johnson, Republican Senator, to Seek Third Term in Wisconsin
author: John McCormick
sentences:

SUBSCRIBE

The decision by Mr. Johnson, who once pledged to retire after two terms, comes as the GOP seeks to win control of the Senate, currently split 50-50.

In 2018, it re-elected Democratic Sen. Tammy Baldwin, one of the chamber's most liberal members, by almost 11 percentage points, while also only barely voting conservative Republican Gov.
Republican Sen. Ron Johnson of Wisconsin, a strong supporter of former President Donald Trump, said he would seek a third term in one of the nation's most politically competitive states.
Mr. Biden won Wisconsin in 2020 by six-tenths of a percentage point, the third-narrowest outcome nationwide and the latest example of the state's long tradition of hard-fought races.
The party in control of the White House traditionally loses seats in midterm elections, voters are feeling squeezed by inflation, and President Biden's popularity has sagged.
A Marquette Law School Poll of registered voters in late October showed 38% said they would vote to re-elect Mr. Johnson, while 52% said they would support someone else.
Since entering the Senate, Mr. Johnson has embraced the outsider's mantle and has tried to establish himself as a leading voice for fiscal restraint.
Republicans are optimistic about their prospects of retaking the House, while facing a tougher fight in their efforts to take control of the Senate.

He is seen as a leading contender to succeed Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R., Ky.), should Mr. McConnell leave the chamber.
Close to a dozen Democrats are jockeying ahead of an August primary to win the right to challenge Mr. Johnson in the general election.
With a significant number of swing voters, Wisconsin has elected both progressives and conservatives to statewide office.
The move means Republicans won't have to scramble to find another candidate ahead of the party primary this summer.
